FuncDescriptionShort: The reverse direction (Inverse) One Dimensional Discrete Fourier Transform
FuncDescriptionLong: This function simply reverses the effects of the forward transform.  It takes as its input either a logical-runtime series containing complex number elements, or, alternatively, a logical-runtime series containing amplitude-phase pair elements; runs them through a reverse-transform summation formula; and outputs the original signal (time series or spatial series or arbitrary discrete series)  that was input into the TD_DFFT to generate the Fourier coefficients.

Description: It takes as its input a logical-runtime series, aka, 'a 1D array',  that has been populated previously with Fourier Transform coefficients.  The calculated coefficients may exist in either the form of : complex numbers - real and imaginary pairs; or exist as amplitude-phase pairs.
Input.LangName: data or object or newdata or ... --> Langauges team can work with UAF team to come up with this field

Description: The output of the inverse transform is a logical result series - time series or spatial series or arbitrary series â€“ containing a row-index and magnitudes.  The magnitudes will always be expressed as complex numbers.  The result will be indexed by a sequence of monotonically increasing integers beginning from 0.
The TD_IDFFT function only generates a primary result set.  There are no secondary or tertiary result sets generated by this function.

The TD_IDFFT transforms the input frequency domain series containing the Fourier coefficients back into a time/space domain series.    The elements of the result series are either CONTENT(COMPLEX) or CONTENT(MULTIVAR_COMPLEX).
Output.LangName: data or object or newdata or ... --> Langauges team can work with UAF team to come up with this field

Params.Name: HUMAN_READABLE
Description: Required Parameter when input rows are in raw format.  Informs the TD_IDDFT as to whether the incoming DFFT coefficient rows are in a human-readable / plottable form; or if they are output in the raw-form, which is equivalent to how the 'R' and 'PYTHON' programs produce DFFT results.     A value of '1' means true, output in human readable form; a value of '0' means false, output in raw form.  Default is true - input rows are  in Human Readable format.
